data.sampled: True. In the context of the ABA Model Rules of Professional Conduct, reporting criminal and fraudulent conduct is a breach of professional conduct. Lawyers must report clients with criminal or fraudulent conduct, breaches of confidentiality, or attempts to conceal fraudulent activity, and must provide all necessary information to the proper authorities, as required by ABA 12.040. Lawyers may also take other action as set forth in ABA rules, such as notifying the client and the lawyer of their further legal obligations or liability.

data.sampled: False. According to the ABA Model Rules of Professional Conduct, a lawyer with general experience not considered competent to handle a case involving a specialized field of law is not liable for breach of duty to render a professional service in the specialized field of law in question, but is not entitled to actual judgment in such a case. Therefore, a person with general qualifications who is not a lawyer specializing in the specialized field of law is not liable, but may be held accountable for such breach of duty to render a professional service in the specialized field of law if the lawyer is not competent to do so.
